<Link id="l00001" /><CodeLine lineNumber="1"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">//===-- DependenceAnalysis.cpp - DA Implementation --------------&#42;- C++ -&#42;-===//</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00002" /><CodeLine lineNumber="2"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">//</span></CodeLine>

<Link id="l00006" /><CodeLine lineNumber="6"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">//</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00007" /><CodeLine lineNumber="7"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">//===----------------------------------------------------------------------===//</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00008" /><CodeLine lineNumber="8"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">//</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00009" /><CodeLine lineNumber="9"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// DependenceAnalysis is an LLVM pass that analyses dependences between memory</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00010" /><CodeLine lineNumber="10"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// accesses. Currently, it is an (incomplete) implementation of the approach</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00011" /><CodeLine lineNumber="11"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// described in</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00012" /><CodeLine lineNumber="12"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">//</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00013" /><CodeLine lineNumber="13"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">//            Practical Dependence Testing</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00014" /><CodeLine lineNumber="14"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">//            Goff, Kennedy, Tseng</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00015" /><CodeLine lineNumber="15"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">//            PLDI 1991</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00016" /><CodeLine lineNumber="16"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">//</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00017" /><CodeLine lineNumber="17"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// There&#39;s a single entry point that analyzes the dependence between a pair</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00018" /><CodeLine lineNumber="18"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// of memory references in a function, returning either NULL, for no dependence,</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00019" /><CodeLine lineNumber="19"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// or a more-or-less detailed description of the dependence between them.</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00020" /><CodeLine lineNumber="20"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">//</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00021" /><CodeLine lineNumber="21"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// Currently, the implementation cannot propagate constraints between</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00022" /><CodeLine lineNumber="22"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// coupled RDIV subscripts and lacks a multi-subscript MIV test.</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00023" /><CodeLine lineNumber="23"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// Both of these are conservative weaknesses;</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00024" /><CodeLine lineNumber="24"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// that is, not a source of correctness problems.</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00025" /><CodeLine lineNumber="25"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">//</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00026" /><CodeLine lineNumber="26"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// Since Clang linearizes some array subscripts, the dependence</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00027" /><CodeLine lineNumber="27"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// analysis is using SCEV-&gt;delinearize to recover the representation of multiple</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00028" /><CodeLine lineNumber="28"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// subscripts, and thus avoid the more expensive and less precise MIV tests. The</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00029" /><CodeLine lineNumber="29"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// delinearization is controlled by the flag -da-delinearize.</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00030" /><CodeLine lineNumber="30"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">//</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00031" /><CodeLine lineNumber="31"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// We should pay some careful attention to the possibility of integer overflow</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00032" /><CodeLine lineNumber="32"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// in the implementation of the various tests. This could happen with Add,</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00033" /><CodeLine lineNumber="33"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// Subtract, or Multiply, with both APInt&#39;s and SCEV&#39;s.</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00034" /><CodeLine lineNumber="34"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">//</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00035" /><CodeLine lineNumber="35"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// Some non-linear subscript pairs can be handled by the GCD test</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00036" /><CodeLine lineNumber="36"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// (and perhaps other tests).</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00037" /><CodeLine lineNumber="37"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// Should explore how often these things occur.</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00038" /><CodeLine lineNumber="38"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">//</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00039" /><CodeLine lineNumber="39"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// Finally, it seems like certain test cases expose weaknesses in the SCEV</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00040" /><CodeLine lineNumber="40"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// simplification, especially in the handling of sign and zero extensions.</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00041" /><CodeLine lineNumber="41"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// It could be useful to spend time exploring these.</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00042" /><CodeLine lineNumber="42"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">//</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00043" /><CodeLine lineNumber="43"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// Please note that this is work in progress and the interface is subject to</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00044" /><CodeLine lineNumber="44"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// change.</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00045" /><CodeLine lineNumber="45"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">//</span></CodeLine>

<Link id="l00759" /><CodeLine lineNumber="759"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// Examines the loop nesting of the Src and Dst</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00760" /><CodeLine lineNumber="760"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// instructions and establishes their shared loops. Sets the variables</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00761" /><CodeLine lineNumber="761"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// CommonLevels, SrcLevels, and MaxLevels.</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00762" /><CodeLine lineNumber="762"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// The source and destination instructions needn&#39;t be contained in the same</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00763" /><CodeLine lineNumber="763"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// loop. The routine establishNestingLevels finds the level of most deeply</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00764" /><CodeLine lineNumber="764"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// nested loop that contains them both, CommonLevels. An instruction that&#39;s</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00765" /><CodeLine lineNumber="765"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// not contained in a loop is at level = 0 MaxLevels is equal to the level</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00766" /><CodeLine lineNumber="766"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// of the source plus the level of the destination, minus CommonLevels.</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00767" /><CodeLine lineNumber="767"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// This lets us allocate vectors MaxLevels in length, with room for every</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00768" /><CodeLine lineNumber="768"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// distinct loop referenced in both the source and destination subscripts.</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00769" /><CodeLine lineNumber="769"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// The variable SrcLevels is the nesting depth of the source instruction.</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00770" /><CodeLine lineNumber="770"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// It&#39;s used to help calculate distinct loops referenced by the destination.</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00771" /><CodeLine lineNumber="771"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// Here&#39;s the map from loops to levels:</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00772" /><CodeLine lineNumber="772"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">//            0 - unused</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00773" /><CodeLine lineNumber="773"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">//            1 - outermost common loop</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00774" /><CodeLine lineNumber="774"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">//          ... - other common loops</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00775" /><CodeLine lineNumber="775"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// CommonLevels - innermost common loop</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00776" /><CodeLine lineNumber="776"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">//          ... - loops containing Src but not Dst</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00777" /><CodeLine lineNumber="777"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">//    SrcLevels - innermost loop containing Src but not Dst</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00778" /><CodeLine lineNumber="778"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">//          ... - loops containing Dst but not Src</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00779" /><CodeLine lineNumber="779"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">//    MaxLevels - innermost loops containing Dst but not Src</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00780" /><CodeLine lineNumber="780"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// Consider the follow code fragment:</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00781" /><CodeLine lineNumber="781"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">//   for (a = ...) &#123;</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00782" /><CodeLine lineNumber="782"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">//     for (b = ...) &#123;</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00783" /><CodeLine lineNumber="783"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">//       for (c = ...) &#123;</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00784" /><CodeLine lineNumber="784"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">//         for (d = ...) &#123;</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00785" /><CodeLine lineNumber="785"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">//           A&#91;&#93; = ...;</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00786" /><CodeLine lineNumber="786"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">//         &#125;</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00787" /><CodeLine lineNumber="787"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">//       &#125;</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00788" /><CodeLine lineNumber="788"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">//       for (e = ...) &#123;</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00789" /><CodeLine lineNumber="789"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">//         for (f = ...) &#123;</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00790" /><CodeLine lineNumber="790"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">//           for (g = ...) &#123;</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00791" /><CodeLine lineNumber="791"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">//             ... = A&#91;&#93;;</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00792" /><CodeLine lineNumber="792"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">//           &#125;</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00793" /><CodeLine lineNumber="793"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">//         &#125;</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00794" /><CodeLine lineNumber="794"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">//       &#125;</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00795" /><CodeLine lineNumber="795"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">//     &#125;</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00796" /><CodeLine lineNumber="796"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">//   &#125;</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00797" /><CodeLine lineNumber="797"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// If we&#39;re looking at the possibility of a dependence between the store</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00798" /><CodeLine lineNumber="798"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// to A (the Src) and the load from A (the Dst), we&#39;ll note that they</span></CodeLine>

<Link id="l00800" /><CodeLine lineNumber="800"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// vector for Result will have 2 entries. SrcLevels = 4 and MaxLevels = 7</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00801" /><CodeLine lineNumber="801"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// A map from loop names to loop numbers would look like</span></CodeLine>

<Link id="l00811" /><CodeLine lineNumber="811"><span class="doxyHighlight">  </span><span class="doxyHighlightKeyword">const</span><span class="doxyHighlight"> <a href="/docs/api/namespaces/llvm/isd/#a22ea9cec080dd5f4f47ba234c2f59110a8472e46f9e4db168c5610ecdfb05dbaf">BasicBlock</a> &#42;SrcBlock = <a href="/docs/api/namespaces/anonymous-linkmodules-cpp-/#ab56eb2027bc9c069aa696e54de8b4298a276e79316561733d64abdf00f8e8ae48">Src</a>-&gt;getParent();</span></CodeLine>

<Link id="l01174" /><CodeLine lineNumber="1174"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// When we have a pair of subscripts of the form &#91;c1&#93; and &#91;c2&#93;,</span></CodeLine>

<Link id="l01181" /><CodeLine lineNumber="1181"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">//</span></CodeLine>

<Link id="l01203" /><CodeLine lineNumber="1203"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// strongSIVtest -</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l01204" /><CodeLine lineNumber="1204"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// From the paper, Practical Dependence Testing, Section 4.2.1</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l01205" /><CodeLine lineNumber="1205"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">//</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l01206" /><CodeLine lineNumber="1206"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// When we have a pair of subscripts of the form &#91;c1 + a&#42;i&#93; and &#91;c2 + a&#42;i&#93;,</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l01207" /><CodeLine lineNumber="1207"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// where i is an induction variable, c1 and c2 are loop invariant,</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l01208" /><CodeLine lineNumber="1208"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">//  and a is a constant, we can solve it exactly using the Strong SIV test.</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l01209" /><CodeLine lineNumber="1209"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">//</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l01210" /><CodeLine lineNumber="1210"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// Can prove independence. Failing that, can compute distance (and direction).</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l01211" /><CodeLine lineNumber="1211"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// In the presence of symbolic terms, we can sometimes make progress.</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l01212" /><CodeLine lineNumber="1212"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">//</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l01213" /><CodeLine lineNumber="1213"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// If there&#39;s a dependence,</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l01214" /><CodeLine lineNumber="1214"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">//</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l01215" /><CodeLine lineNumber="1215"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">//    c1 + a&#42;i = c2 + a&#42;i&#39;</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l01216" /><CodeLine lineNumber="1216"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">//</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l01217" /><CodeLine lineNumber="1217"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// The dependence distance is</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l01218" /><CodeLine lineNumber="1218"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">//</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l01219" /><CodeLine lineNumber="1219"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">//    d = i&#39; - i = (c1 - c2)/a</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l01220" /><CodeLine lineNumber="1220"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">//</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l01221" /><CodeLine lineNumber="1221"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// A dependence only exists if d is an integer and abs(d) &lt;= U, where U is the</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l01222" /><CodeLine lineNumber="1222"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// loop&#39;s upper bound. If a dependence exists, the dependence direction is</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l01223" /><CodeLine lineNumber="1223"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// defined as</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l01224" /><CodeLine lineNumber="1224"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">//</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l01225" /><CodeLine lineNumber="1225"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">//                &#123; &lt; if d &gt; 0</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l01226" /><CodeLine lineNumber="1226"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">//    direction = &#123; = if d = 0</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l01227" /><CodeLine lineNumber="1227"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">//                &#123; &gt; if d &lt; 0</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l01228" /><CodeLine lineNumber="1228"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">//</span></CodeLine>

<Link id="l01341" /><CodeLine lineNumber="1341"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// When we have a pair of subscripts of the form &#91;c1 + a&#42;i&#93; and &#91;c2 - a&#42;i&#93;,</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l01342" /><CodeLine lineNumber="1342"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// where i is an induction variable, c1 and c2 are loop invariant,</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l01343" /><CodeLine lineNumber="1343"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// and a is a constant, we can solve it exactly using the</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l01344" /><CodeLine lineNumber="1344"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// Weak-Crossing SIV test.</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l01345" /><CodeLine lineNumber="1345"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">//</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l01346" /><CodeLine lineNumber="1346"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// Given c1 + a&#42;i = c2 - a&#42;i&#39;, we can look for the intersection of</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l01347" /><CodeLine lineNumber="1347"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// the two lines, where i = i&#39;, yielding</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l01348" /><CodeLine lineNumber="1348"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">//</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l01349" /><CodeLine lineNumber="1349"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">//    c1 + a&#42;i = c2 - a&#42;i</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l01350" /><CodeLine lineNumber="1350"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">//    2a&#42;i = c2 - c1</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l01351" /><CodeLine lineNumber="1351"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">//    i = (c2 - c1)/2a</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l01352" /><CodeLine lineNumber="1352"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">//</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l01353" /><CodeLine lineNumber="1353"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// If i &lt; 0, there is no dependence.</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l01354" /><CodeLine lineNumber="1354"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// If i &gt; upperbound, there is no dependence.</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l01355" /><CodeLine lineNumber="1355"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// If i = 0 (i.e., if c1 = c2), there&#39;s a dependence with distance = 0</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l01356" /><CodeLine lineNumber="1356"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// If i = upperbound, there&#39;s a dependence with distance = 0</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l01357" /><CodeLine lineNumber="1357"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// If i is integral, there&#39;s a dependence (all directions).</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l01358" /><CodeLine lineNumber="1358"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// If the non-integer part = 1/2, there&#39;s a dependence (&lt;&gt; directions).</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l01359" /><CodeLine lineNumber="1359"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// Otherwise, there&#39;s no dependence.</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l01360" /><CodeLine lineNumber="1360"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">//</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l01361" /><CodeLine lineNumber="1361"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// Can prove independence. Failing that,</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l01362" /><CodeLine lineNumber="1362"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// can sometimes refine the directions.</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l01363" /><CodeLine lineNumber="1363"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// Can determine iteration for splitting.</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l01364" /><CodeLine lineNumber="1364"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">//</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l01365" /><CodeLine lineNumber="1365"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// Return true if dependence disproved.</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l01366" /><CodeLine lineNumber="1366"><span class="doxyHighlightKeywordType">bool</span><span class="doxyHighlight"> DependenceInfo::weakCrossingSIVtest(</span></CodeLine>

<Link id="l01552" /><CodeLine lineNumber="1552"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">//</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l01553" /><CodeLine lineNumber="1553"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">//        Dependence Analysis for Supercomputing</span></CodeLine>

<Link id="l01556" /><CodeLine lineNumber="1556"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">//</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l01557" /><CodeLine lineNumber="1557"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// It&#39;s slower than the specialized tests (strong SIV, weak-zero SIV, etc),</span></CodeLine>

<Link id="l01728" /><CodeLine lineNumber="1728"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// weakZeroSrcSIVtest -</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l01729" /><CodeLine lineNumber="1729"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// From the paper, Practical Dependence Testing, Section 4.2.2</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l01730" /><CodeLine lineNumber="1730"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">//</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l01731" /><CodeLine lineNumber="1731"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// When we have a pair of subscripts of the form &#91;c1&#93; and &#91;c2 + a&#42;i&#93;,</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l01732" /><CodeLine lineNumber="1732"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// where i is an induction variable, c1 and c2 are loop invariant,</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l01733" /><CodeLine lineNumber="1733"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// and a is a constant, we can solve it exactly using the</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l01734" /><CodeLine lineNumber="1734"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// Weak-Zero SIV test.</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l01735" /><CodeLine lineNumber="1735"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">//</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l01736" /><CodeLine lineNumber="1736"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// Given</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l01737" /><CodeLine lineNumber="1737"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">//</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l01738" /><CodeLine lineNumber="1738"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">//    c1 = c2 + a&#42;i</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l01739" /><CodeLine lineNumber="1739"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">//</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l01740" /><CodeLine lineNumber="1740"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// we get</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l01741" /><CodeLine lineNumber="1741"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">//</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l01742" /><CodeLine lineNumber="1742"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">//    (c1 - c2)/a = i</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l01743" /><CodeLine lineNumber="1743"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">//</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l01744" /><CodeLine lineNumber="1744"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// If i is not an integer, there&#39;s no dependence.</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l01745" /><CodeLine lineNumber="1745"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// If i &lt; 0 or &gt; UB, there&#39;s no dependence.</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l01746" /><CodeLine lineNumber="1746"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// If i = 0, the direction is &gt;= and peeling the</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l01747" /><CodeLine lineNumber="1747"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// 1st iteration will break the dependence.</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l01748" /><CodeLine lineNumber="1748"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// If i = UB, the direction is &lt;= and peeling the</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l01749" /><CodeLine lineNumber="1749"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// last iteration will break the dependence.</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l01750" /><CodeLine lineNumber="1750"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// Otherwise, the direction is &#42;.</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l01751" /><CodeLine lineNumber="1751"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">//</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l01752" /><CodeLine lineNumber="1752"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// Can prove independence. Failing that, we can sometimes refine</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l01753" /><CodeLine lineNumber="1753"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// the directions. Can sometimes show that first or last</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l01754" /><CodeLine lineNumber="1754"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// iteration carries all the dependences (so worth peeling).</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l01755" /><CodeLine lineNumber="1755"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">//</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l01756" /><CodeLine lineNumber="1756"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// (see also weakZeroDstSIVtest)</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l01757" /><CodeLine lineNumber="1757"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">//</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l01758" /><CodeLine lineNumber="1758"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// Return true if dependence disproved.</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l01759" /><CodeLine lineNumber="1759"><span class="doxyHighlightKeywordType">bool</span><span class="doxyHighlight"> DependenceInfo::weakZeroSrcSIVtest(</span><span class="doxyHighlightKeyword">const</span><span class="doxyHighlight"> SCEV &#42;DstCoeff,</span></CodeLine>

<Link id="l01765" /><CodeLine lineNumber="1765"><span class="doxyHighlight">  </span><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// For the WeakSIV test, it&#39;s possible the loop isn&#39;t common to</span></CodeLine>

<Link id="l01838" /><CodeLine lineNumber="1838"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// weakZeroDstSIVtest -</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l01839" /><CodeLine lineNumber="1839"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// From the paper, Practical Dependence Testing, Section 4.2.2</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l01840" /><CodeLine lineNumber="1840"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">//</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l01841" /><CodeLine lineNumber="1841"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// When we have a pair of subscripts of the form &#91;c1 + a&#42;i&#93; and &#91;c2&#93;,</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l01842" /><CodeLine lineNumber="1842"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// where i is an induction variable, c1 and c2 are loop invariant,</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l01843" /><CodeLine lineNumber="1843"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// and a is a constant, we can solve it exactly using the</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l01844" /><CodeLine lineNumber="1844"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// Weak-Zero SIV test.</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l01845" /><CodeLine lineNumber="1845"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">//</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l01846" /><CodeLine lineNumber="1846"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// Given</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l01847" /><CodeLine lineNumber="1847"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">//</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l01848" /><CodeLine lineNumber="1848"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">//    c1 + a&#42;i = c2</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l01849" /><CodeLine lineNumber="1849"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">//</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l01850" /><CodeLine lineNumber="1850"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// we get</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l01851" /><CodeLine lineNumber="1851"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">//</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l01852" /><CodeLine lineNumber="1852"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">//    i = (c2 - c1)/a</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l01853" /><CodeLine lineNumber="1853"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">//</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l01854" /><CodeLine lineNumber="1854"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// If i is not an integer, there&#39;s no dependence.</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l01855" /><CodeLine lineNumber="1855"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// If i &lt; 0 or &gt; UB, there&#39;s no dependence.</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l01856" /><CodeLine lineNumber="1856"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// If i = 0, the direction is &lt;= and peeling the</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l01857" /><CodeLine lineNumber="1857"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// 1st iteration will break the dependence.</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l01858" /><CodeLine lineNumber="1858"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// If i = UB, the direction is &gt;= and peeling the</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l01859" /><CodeLine lineNumber="1859"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// last iteration will break the dependence.</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l01860" /><CodeLine lineNumber="1860"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// Otherwise, the direction is &#42;.</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l01861" /><CodeLine lineNumber="1861"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">//</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l01862" /><CodeLine lineNumber="1862"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// Can prove independence. Failing that, we can sometimes refine</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l01863" /><CodeLine lineNumber="1863"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// the directions. Can sometimes show that first or last</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l01864" /><CodeLine lineNumber="1864"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// iteration carries all the dependences (so worth peeling).</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l01865" /><CodeLine lineNumber="1865"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">//</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l01866" /><CodeLine lineNumber="1866"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// (see also weakZeroSrcSIVtest)</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l01867" /><CodeLine lineNumber="1867"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">//</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l01868" /><CodeLine lineNumber="1868"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// Return true if dependence disproved.</span></CodeLine>

<Link id="l02068" /><CodeLine lineNumber="2068"></CodeLine>
<Link id="l02069" /><CodeLine lineNumber="2069"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// symbolicRDIVtest -</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l02070" /><CodeLine lineNumber="2070"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// In Section 4.5 of the Practical Dependence Testing paper,the authors</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l02071" /><CodeLine lineNumber="2071"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// introduce a special case of Banerjee&#39;s Inequalities (also called the</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l02072" /><CodeLine lineNumber="2072"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// Extreme-Value Test) that can handle some of the SIV and RDIV cases,</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l02073" /><CodeLine lineNumber="2073"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// particularly cases with symbolics. Since it&#39;s only able to disprove</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l02074" /><CodeLine lineNumber="2074"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// dependence (not compute distances or directions), we&#39;ll use it as a</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l02075" /><CodeLine lineNumber="2075"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// fall back for the other tests.</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l02076" /><CodeLine lineNumber="2076"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">//</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l02077" /><CodeLine lineNumber="2077"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// When we have a pair of subscripts of the form &#91;c1 + a1&#42;i&#93; and &#91;c2 + a2&#42;j&#93;</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l02078" /><CodeLine lineNumber="2078"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// where i and j are induction variables and c1 and c2 are loop invariants,</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l02079" /><CodeLine lineNumber="2079"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// we can use the symbolic tests to disprove some dependences, serving as a</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l02080" /><CodeLine lineNumber="2080"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// backup for the RDIV test. Note that i and j can be the same variable,</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l02081" /><CodeLine lineNumber="2081"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// letting this test serve as a backup for the various SIV tests.</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l02082" /><CodeLine lineNumber="2082"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">//</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l02083" /><CodeLine lineNumber="2083"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// For a dependence to exist, c1 + a1&#42;i must equal c2 + a2&#42;j for some</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l02084" /><CodeLine lineNumber="2084"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">//  0 &lt;= i &lt;= N1 and some 0 &lt;= j &lt;= N2, where N1 and N2 are the (normalized)</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l02085" /><CodeLine lineNumber="2085"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// loop bounds for the i and j loops, respectively. So, ...</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l02086" /><CodeLine lineNumber="2086"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">//</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l02087" /><CodeLine lineNumber="2087"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// c1 + a1&#42;i = c2 + a2&#42;j</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l02088" /><CodeLine lineNumber="2088"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// a1&#42;i - a2&#42;j = c2 - c1</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l02089" /><CodeLine lineNumber="2089"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">//</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l02090" /><CodeLine lineNumber="2090"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// To test for a dependence, we compute c2 - c1 and make sure it&#39;s in the</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l02091" /><CodeLine lineNumber="2091"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// range of the maximum and minimum possible values of a1&#42;i - a2&#42;j.</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l02092" /><CodeLine lineNumber="2092"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// Considering the signs of a1 and a2, we have 4 possible cases:</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l02093" /><CodeLine lineNumber="2093"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">//</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l02094" /><CodeLine lineNumber="2094"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// 1) If a1 &gt;= 0 and a2 &gt;= 0, then</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l02095" /><CodeLine lineNumber="2095"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">//        a1&#42;0 - a2&#42;N2 &lt;= c2 - c1 &lt;= a1&#42;N1 - a2&#42;0</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l02096" /><CodeLine lineNumber="2096"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">//              -a2&#42;N2 &lt;= c2 - c1 &lt;= a1&#42;N1</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l02097" /><CodeLine lineNumber="2097"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">//</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l02098" /><CodeLine lineNumber="2098"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// 2) If a1 &gt;= 0 and a2 &lt;= 0, then</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l02099" /><CodeLine lineNumber="2099"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">//        a1&#42;0 - a2&#42;0 &lt;= c2 - c1 &lt;= a1&#42;N1 - a2&#42;N2</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l02100" /><CodeLine lineNumber="2100"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">//                  0 &lt;= c2 - c1 &lt;= a1&#42;N1 - a2&#42;N2</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l02101" /><CodeLine lineNumber="2101"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">//</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l02102" /><CodeLine lineNumber="2102"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// 3) If a1 &lt;= 0 and a2 &gt;= 0, then</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l02103" /><CodeLine lineNumber="2103"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">//        a1&#42;N1 - a2&#42;N2 &lt;= c2 - c1 &lt;= a1&#42;0 - a2&#42;0</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l02104" /><CodeLine lineNumber="2104"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">//        a1&#42;N1 - a2&#42;N2 &lt;= c2 - c1 &lt;= 0</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l02105" /><CodeLine lineNumber="2105"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">//</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l02106" /><CodeLine lineNumber="2106"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// 4) If a1 &lt;= 0 and a2 &lt;= 0, then</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l02107" /><CodeLine lineNumber="2107"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">//        a1&#42;N1 - a2&#42;0  &lt;= c2 - c1 &lt;= a1&#42;0 - a2&#42;N2</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l02108" /><CodeLine lineNumber="2108"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">//        a1&#42;N1         &lt;= c2 - c1 &lt;=       -a2&#42;N2</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l02109" /><CodeLine lineNumber="2109"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">//</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l02110" /><CodeLine lineNumber="2110"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// return true if dependence disproved</span></CodeLine>

<Link id="l02572" /><CodeLine lineNumber="2572"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// banerjeeMIVtest -</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l02573" /><CodeLine lineNumber="2573"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// Use Banerjee&#39;s Inequalities to test an MIV subscript pair.</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l02574" /><CodeLine lineNumber="2574"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// (Wolfe, in the race-car book, calls this the Extreme Value Test.)</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l02575" /><CodeLine lineNumber="2575"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// Generally follows the discussion in Section 2.5.2 of</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l02576" /><CodeLine lineNumber="2576"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">//</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l02577" /><CodeLine lineNumber="2577"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">//    Optimizing Supercompilers for Supercomputers</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l02578" /><CodeLine lineNumber="2578"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">//    Michael Wolfe</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l02579" /><CodeLine lineNumber="2579"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">//</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l02580" /><CodeLine lineNumber="2580"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// The inequalities given on page 25 are simplified in that loops are</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l02581" /><CodeLine lineNumber="2581"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// normalized so that the lower bound is always 0 and the stride is always 1</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l02582" /><CodeLine lineNumber="2582"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// For example, Wolfe gives</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l02583" /><CodeLine lineNumber="2583"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">//</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l02584" /><CodeLine lineNumber="2584"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">//     LB^&lt;&#95;k = (A^-&#95;k - B&#95;k)^- (U&#95;k - L&#95;k - N&#95;k) + (A&#95;k - B&#95;k)L&#95;k - B&#95;k N&#95;k</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l02585" /><CodeLine lineNumber="2585"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">//</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l02586" /><CodeLine lineNumber="2586"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// where A&#95;k is the coefficient of the kth index in the source subscript,</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l02587" /><CodeLine lineNumber="2587"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// B&#95;k is the coefficient of the kth index in the destination subscript,</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l02588" /><CodeLine lineNumber="2588"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// U&#95;k is the upper bound of the kth index, L&#95;k is the lower bound of the Kth</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l02589" /><CodeLine lineNumber="2589"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// index, and N&#95;k is the stride of the kth index. Since all loops are normalized</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l02590" /><CodeLine lineNumber="2590"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// by the SCEV package, N&#95;k = 1 and L&#95;k = 0, allowing us to simplify the</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l02591" /><CodeLine lineNumber="2591"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// equation to</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l02592" /><CodeLine lineNumber="2592"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">//</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l02593" /><CodeLine lineNumber="2593"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">//     LB^&lt;&#95;k = (A^-&#95;k - B&#95;k)^- (U&#95;k - 0 - 1) + (A&#95;k - B&#95;k)0 - B&#95;k 1</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l02594" /><CodeLine lineNumber="2594"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">//            = (A^-&#95;k - B&#95;k)^- (U&#95;k - 1)  - B&#95;k</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l02595" /><CodeLine lineNumber="2595"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">//</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l02596" /><CodeLine lineNumber="2596"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// Similar simplifications are possible for the other equations.</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l02597" /><CodeLine lineNumber="2597"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">//</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l02598" /><CodeLine lineNumber="2598"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// When we can&#39;t determine the number of iterations for a loop,</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l02599" /><CodeLine lineNumber="2599"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// we use NULL as an indicator for the worst case, infinity.</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l02600" /><CodeLine lineNumber="2600"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// When computing the upper bound, NULL denotes +inf;</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l02601" /><CodeLine lineNumber="2601"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// for the lower bound, NULL denotes -inf.</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l02602" /><CodeLine lineNumber="2602"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">//</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l02603" /><CodeLine lineNumber="2603"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// Return true if dependence disproved.</span></CodeLine>

<Link id="l03681" /><CodeLine lineNumber="3681"><span class="doxyHighlight">  </span><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// Partition subscripts into separable and minimally-coupled groups</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l03682" /><CodeLine lineNumber="3682"><span class="doxyHighlight">  </span><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// Algorithm in paper is algorithmically better;</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l03683" /><CodeLine lineNumber="3683"><span class="doxyHighlight">  </span><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// this may be faster in practice. Check someday.</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l03684" /><CodeLine lineNumber="3684"><span class="doxyHighlight">  </span><span class="doxyHighlightComment">//</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l03685" /><CodeLine lineNumber="3685"><span class="doxyHighlight">  </span><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// Here&#39;s an example of how it works. Consider this code:</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l03686" /><CodeLine lineNumber="3686"><span class="doxyHighlight">  </span><span class="doxyHighlightComment">//</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l03687" /><CodeLine lineNumber="3687"><span class="doxyHighlight">  </span><span class="doxyHighlightComment">//   for (i = ...) &#123;</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l03688" /><CodeLine lineNumber="3688"><span class="doxyHighlight">  </span><span class="doxyHighlightComment">//     for (j = ...) &#123;</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l03689" /><CodeLine lineNumber="3689"><span class="doxyHighlight">  </span><span class="doxyHighlightComment">//       for (k = ...) &#123;</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l03690" /><CodeLine lineNumber="3690"><span class="doxyHighlight">  </span><span class="doxyHighlightComment">//         for (l = ...) &#123;</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l03691" /><CodeLine lineNumber="3691"><span class="doxyHighlight">  </span><span class="doxyHighlightComment">//           for (m = ...) &#123;</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l03692" /><CodeLine lineNumber="3692"><span class="doxyHighlight">  </span><span class="doxyHighlightComment">//             A&#91;i&#93;&#91;j&#93;&#91;k&#93;&#91;m&#93; = ...;</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l03693" /><CodeLine lineNumber="3693"><span class="doxyHighlight">  </span><span class="doxyHighlightComment">//             ... = A&#91;0&#93;&#91;j&#93;&#91;l&#93;&#91;i + j&#93;;</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l03694" /><CodeLine lineNumber="3694"><span class="doxyHighlight">  </span><span class="doxyHighlightComment">//           &#125;</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l03695" /><CodeLine lineNumber="3695"><span class="doxyHighlight">  </span><span class="doxyHighlightComment">//         &#125;</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l03696" /><CodeLine lineNumber="3696"><span class="doxyHighlight">  </span><span class="doxyHighlightComment">//       &#125;</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l03697" /><CodeLine lineNumber="3697"><span class="doxyHighlight">  </span><span class="doxyHighlightComment">//     &#125;</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l03698" /><CodeLine lineNumber="3698"><span class="doxyHighlight">  </span><span class="doxyHighlightComment">//   &#125;</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l03699" /><CodeLine lineNumber="3699"><span class="doxyHighlight">  </span><span class="doxyHighlightComment">//</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l03700" /><CodeLine lineNumber="3700"><span class="doxyHighlight">  </span><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// There are 4 subscripts here:</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l03701" /><CodeLine lineNumber="3701"><span class="doxyHighlight">  </span><span class="doxyHighlightComment">//    0 &#91;i&#93; and &#91;0&#93;</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l03702" /><CodeLine lineNumber="3702"><span class="doxyHighlight">  </span><span class="doxyHighlightComment">//    1 &#91;j&#93; and &#91;j&#93;</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l03703" /><CodeLine lineNumber="3703"><span class="doxyHighlight">  </span><span class="doxyHighlightComment">//    2 &#91;k&#93; and &#91;l&#93;</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l03704" /><CodeLine lineNumber="3704"><span class="doxyHighlight">  </span><span class="doxyHighlightComment">//    3 &#91;m&#93; and &#91;i + j&#93;</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l03705" /><CodeLine lineNumber="3705"><span class="doxyHighlight">  </span><span class="doxyHighlightComment">//</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l03706" /><CodeLine lineNumber="3706"><span class="doxyHighlight">  </span><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// We&#39;ve already classified each subscript pair as ZIV, SIV, etc.,</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l03707" /><CodeLine lineNumber="3707"><span class="doxyHighlight">  </span><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// and collected all the loops mentioned by pair P in Pair&#91;P&#93;.Loops.</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l03708" /><CodeLine lineNumber="3708"><span class="doxyHighlight">  </span><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// In addition, we&#39;ve initialized Pair&#91;P&#93;.GroupLoops to Pair&#91;P&#93;.Loops</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l03709" /><CodeLine lineNumber="3709"><span class="doxyHighlight">  </span><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// and set Pair&#91;P&#93;.Group = &#123;P&#125;.</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l03710" /><CodeLine lineNumber="3710"><span class="doxyHighlight">  </span><span class="doxyHighlightComment">//</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l03711" /><CodeLine lineNumber="3711"><span class="doxyHighlight">  </span><span class="doxyHighlightComment">//      Src Dst    Classification Loops  GroupLoops Group</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l03712" /><CodeLine lineNumber="3712"><span class="doxyHighlight">  </span><span class="doxyHighlightComment">//    0 &#91;i&#93; &#91;0&#93;         SIV       &#123;1&#125;      &#123;1&#125;        &#123;0&#125;</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l03713" /><CodeLine lineNumber="3713"><span class="doxyHighlight">  </span><span class="doxyHighlightComment">//    1 &#91;j&#93; &#91;j&#93;         SIV       &#123;2&#125;      &#123;2&#125;        &#123;1&#125;</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l03714" /><CodeLine lineNumber="3714"><span class="doxyHighlight">  </span><span class="doxyHighlightComment">//    2 &#91;k&#93; &#91;l&#93;         RDIV      &#123;3,4&#125;    &#123;3,4&#125;      &#123;2&#125;</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l03715" /><CodeLine lineNumber="3715"><span class="doxyHighlight">  </span><span class="doxyHighlightComment">//    3 &#91;m&#93; &#91;i + j&#93;     MIV       &#123;1,2,5&#125;  &#123;1,2,5&#125;    &#123;3&#125;</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l03716" /><CodeLine lineNumber="3716"><span class="doxyHighlight">  </span><span class="doxyHighlightComment">//</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l03717" /><CodeLine lineNumber="3717"><span class="doxyHighlight">  </span><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// For each subscript SI 0 .. 3, we consider each remaining subscript, SJ.</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l03718" /><CodeLine lineNumber="3718"><span class="doxyHighlight">  </span><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// So, 0 is compared against 1, 2, and 3; 1 is compared against 2 and 3, etc.</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l03719" /><CodeLine lineNumber="3719"><span class="doxyHighlight">  </span><span class="doxyHighlightComment">//</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l03720" /><CodeLine lineNumber="3720"><span class="doxyHighlight">  </span><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// We begin by comparing 0 and 1 The intersection of the GroupLoops is empty.</span></CodeLine>

<Link id="l03977" /><CodeLine lineNumber="3977"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// getSplitIteration -</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l03978" /><CodeLine lineNumber="3978"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// Rather than spend rarely-used space recording the splitting iteration</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l03979" /><CodeLine lineNumber="3979"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// during the Weak-Crossing SIV test, we re-compute it on demand.</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l03980" /><CodeLine lineNumber="3980"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// The re-computation is basically a repeat of the entire dependence test,</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l03981" /><CodeLine lineNumber="3981"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// though simplified since we know that the dependence exists.</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l03982" /><CodeLine lineNumber="3982"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// It&#39;s tedious, since we must go through all propagations, etc.</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l03983" /><CodeLine lineNumber="3983"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">//</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l03984" /><CodeLine lineNumber="3984"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// Care is required to keep this code up to date with respect to the routine</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l03985" /><CodeLine lineNumber="3985"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// above, depends().</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l03986" /><CodeLine lineNumber="3986"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">//</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l03987" /><CodeLine lineNumber="3987"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// Generally, the dependence analyzer will be used to build</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l03988" /><CodeLine lineNumber="3988"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// a dependence graph for a function (basically a map from instructions</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l03989" /><CodeLine lineNumber="3989"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// to dependences). Looking for cycles in the graph shows us loops</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l03990" /><CodeLine lineNumber="3990"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// that cannot be trivially vectorized/parallelized.</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l03991" /><CodeLine lineNumber="3991"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">//</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l03992" /><CodeLine lineNumber="3992"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// We can try to improve the situation by examining all the dependences</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l03993" /><CodeLine lineNumber="3993"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// that make up the cycle, looking for ones we can break.</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l03994" /><CodeLine lineNumber="3994"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// Sometimes, peeling the first or last iteration of a loop will break</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l03995" /><CodeLine lineNumber="3995"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// dependences, and we&#39;ve got flags for those possibilities.</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l03996" /><CodeLine lineNumber="3996"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// Sometimes, splitting a loop at some other iteration will do the trick,</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l03997" /><CodeLine lineNumber="3997"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// and we&#39;ve got a flag for that case. Rather than waste the space to</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l03998" /><CodeLine lineNumber="3998"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// record the exact iteration (since we rarely know), we provide</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l03999" /><CodeLine lineNumber="3999"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// a method that calculates the iteration. It&#39;s a drag that it must work</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l04000" /><CodeLine lineNumber="4000"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// from scratch, but wonderful in that it&#39;s possible.</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l04001" /><CodeLine lineNumber="4001"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">//</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l04002" /><CodeLine lineNumber="4002"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// Here&#39;s an example:</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l04003" /><CodeLine lineNumber="4003"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">//</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l04004" /><CodeLine lineNumber="4004"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">//    for (i = 0; i &lt; 10; i++)</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l04005" /><CodeLine lineNumber="4005"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">//        A&#91;i&#93; = ...</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l04006" /><CodeLine lineNumber="4006"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">//        ... = A&#91;11 - i&#93;</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l04007" /><CodeLine lineNumber="4007"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">//</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l04008" /><CodeLine lineNumber="4008"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// There&#39;s a loop-carried flow dependence from the store to the load,</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l04009" /><CodeLine lineNumber="4009"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// found by the weak-crossing SIV test. The dependence will have a flag,</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l04010" /><CodeLine lineNumber="4010"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// indicating that the dependence can be broken by splitting the loop.</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l04011" /><CodeLine lineNumber="4011"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// Calling getSplitIteration will return 5</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l04012" /><CodeLine lineNumber="4012"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// Splitting the loop breaks the dependence, like so:</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l04013" /><CodeLine lineNumber="4013"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">//</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l04014" /><CodeLine lineNumber="4014"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">//    for (i = 0; i &lt;= 5; i++)</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l04015" /><CodeLine lineNumber="4015"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">//        A&#91;i&#93; = ...</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l04016" /><CodeLine lineNumber="4016"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">//        ... = A&#91;11 - i&#93;</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l04017" /><CodeLine lineNumber="4017"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">//    for (i = 6; i &lt; 10; i++)</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l04018" /><CodeLine lineNumber="4018"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">//        A&#91;i&#93; = ...</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l04019" /><CodeLine lineNumber="4019"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">//        ... = A&#91;11 - i&#93;</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l04020" /><CodeLine lineNumber="4020"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">//</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l04021" /><CodeLine lineNumber="4021"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// breaks the dependence and allows us to vectorize/parallelize</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l04022" /><CodeLine lineNumber="4022"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// both loops.</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l04023" /><CodeLine lineNumber="4023" lineLink="/docs/api/classes/llvm/dependenceinfo/#a110f1f473cbb5a42bf9c82973ac9101c"><span class="doxyHighlightKeyword">const</span><span class="doxyHighlight"> <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/scev">SCEV</a> &#42;<a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/dependenceinfo/#a110f1f473cbb5a42bf9c82973ac9101c">DependenceInfo::getSplitIteration</a>(</span><span class="doxyHighlightKeyword">const</span><span class="doxyHighlight"> <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/dependence">Dependence</a> &amp;Dep,</span></CodeLine>
